item.title: How The Times Covers Cartels and Other Criminal Enterprises
item.description: Cultivating sources. Verifying claims. Staying safe. After the death of El Mencho, four journalists share their approach to this difficult, dangerous work.
item.dc:creator: Megan DiTrolio, Paulina Villegas, Jack Nicas, Maria Abi-Habib and Lauren Katzenberg
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The remnants of retaliatory violence, including burned vehicles, was evident along the highway between Guadalajara and Tapalpa, in Jalisco state.

item.title: U.S. Has Annexed Canada in Toronto Artist’s Speculative Series
item.description: A speculative public art series that began in alleyways and on buildings and a tennis court fence is opening as a chilling new show at Western University.
item.dc:creator: Shawna Richer
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: The artist Dara Vandor with a plaque from her project “Pax Americana” at the Weldon Library on the campus of Western University.

item.title: Trump Gives Green Light to Private Oil Sales to Cuba
item.description: After blocking foreign oil shipments, the Trump administration is now allowing small amounts of oil to enter Cuba — as long as they circumvent government hands.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and David C. Adams
item.media:credit: Yamil Lage/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Nico Lopez oil refinery in Havana this month.

item.title: The Bloody Rise and Fall of Mexico’s Top Crime Boss
item.description: El Mencho’s brutality and business acumen put him atop the cartel world, until he made a fatal mistake.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Paulina Villegas and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: After Mexican forces killed a notorious cartel kingpin on Sunday, his followers set fire to hundreds of vehicles, like this one beside a highway in Jalisco state.

item.title: Carney Visiting India, Australia and Japan to Build Canada’s ‘Middle Power’ Bonds
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney visits India, Australia and Japan seeking deals to strengthen his country’s links to Indo-Pacific powers and break Canada’s dependence on the United States.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada, with his wife, Diana Fox Carney, arriving in Mumbai, India, on Friday.

item.title: After 50 Years in the Shadows, a Tenacious First-Time Novelist Steps Out Front
item.description: For 50 years, Patricia Finn kept to the background and told other people’s stories. Now, in “The Golden Boy,” she’s finally telling one of her own.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Life does have a way of rearranging your plans,” says Patricia Finn, in her Vancouver home,

item.title: Trump’s Foreign Policy: Resurrecting Empire
item.description: President Trump’s approach is a revival of the mission of empire — acquiring the territories and resources of sovereign peoples.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio, right, has been leading the Trump administration’s foreign policy.

item.title: After a Speedboat Shootout in Cuba, There are More Questions Than Answers
item.description: The Cuban government’s account of a supposed armed raid into its territory was called into question after one of the men identified as being on the boat turned up in Miami.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Adalberto Roque/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Cuban coast guard ships docked at the Port of Havana on Thursday.

item.title: Will World Cup Games in Mexico Be Affected by Cartel Boss Killing?
item.description: Safety questions linger since the country is set to host matches in the world’s largest sporting event, the FIFA World Cup.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Cristopher Rogel Blanquet for The New York Times
item.media:description: A police officer patrolling the historic center of Mexico City on Monday.

item.title: Regime Change in Cuba Appeals to Trump but Carries Risks
item.description: The Trump administration is signaling a different approach, after demanding an end to Cuba’s communist leadership.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Norlys Perez/Reuters
item.media:description: “Cuba does not kneel,” the country’s president, Miguel Díaz-Canel, center, told a state-run newspaper this month.

item.title: Venezuela’s Capital, Laid Low by Misrule, Is Stirring Back to Life
item.description: New restaurants are popping up in Caracas. Nightclubs are bursting at the seams. The streets are eerily safe — with big exceptions. Could a revival be on the horizon?
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Caracas “has the wages of Zimbabwe, the public services of Bangladesh and the prices of New York,” a political analyst said.

item.title: A 48-Hour Layover in Montreal With an Airline Pilot
item.description: On a recent stopover, the writer savors the wintry charms of this Canadian city, taking time out for a little urban skiing, bagels and his favorite Leonard Cohen songs.
item.dc:creator: Mark Vanhoenacker and Nasuna Stuart-Ulin
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times

item.title: What We Know About the Gun Battle Off the Coast of Cuba
item.description: Four armed Cubans aboard a Florida-based speedboat died in a gunfight with Cuban border troops on Wednesday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Frances Robles, Jack Nicas, Eric Schmitt and Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Adalberto Roque/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Cuban Coast Guard ships docked at the port of Havana on Wednesday.

item.title: Vessels Have Clashed With Cuban Border Forces Before
item.description: On Wednesday, a Florida-registered speedboat entered Cuban waters and some on board exchanged gunfire with Cuban troops. Two such armed clashes occurred in 2022.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Ramon Espinosa/Associated Press
item.media:description: In 2022, Cuba’s Ministry of Interior announced that it had intercepted a total of 13 speedboats engaged in migrant-smuggling that year. They also intercepted other vessels, like the one above on Dec. 12 of that year.

item.title: Inside Tapalpa, the Town in Mexico Where El Mencho Made His Last Stand
item.description: Times reporters visiting Tapalpa found a serene town in shock after Sunday’s raid on its outskirts left dozens dead and people fleeing. And, surprisingly, no police or military presence where the battle took place.
item.dc:creator: Paulina Villegas and César Rodríguez
item.media:credit: César Rodríguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town of Tapalpa, in Jalisco state, Mexico, is a stronghold of the Jalisco New Generation Cartel.

item.title: Maduro’s Lawyer Says U.S. is Blocking Venezuela From Paying Legal Fees
item.description: The Treasury Department is interfering with Nicolás Maduro’s constitutional right to counsel, his lawyer argued. Mr. Maduro, the Venezuelan leader, faces federal charges.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich
item.category: Office of Foreign Assets Control (United States Treasury)
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Barry Pollack, carrying a folder, is representing the Venezuelan president, Nicolás Maduro, who is charged with federal crimes.

item.title: Trump’s speech gets a mixed reaction around the world.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump delivering his State of the Union address in Washington on Tuesday.

item.title: Cuban Government Kills 4 in Gunfire Exchange Aboard Florida Speedboat
item.description: Four people aboard a Florida-based speedboat died in a gunfight with Cuban border troops near the island nation’s coast, the Cuban Interior Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Frances Robles, Jack Nicas and Eric Schmitt

item.title: Brazil’s Supreme Court Convicts Four Men in Murder of Marielle Franco
item.description: Two politicians and two former police officers were found guilty in the assassination of a rival, Marielle Franco, a Rio de Janeiro city councilwoman who fought corruption and violence.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Renan Olaz/Rio De Janeiro Municipal Chamber
item.media:description: Marielle Franco, a member of Rio de Janeiro’s City Council, leading a session in 2017 at the municipal chamber in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: Inside Nicolás Maduro’s Last Days as Venezuela’s Leader
item.description: The Venezuelan leader overestimated his strength and misread his exchange with President Trump in the decisive weeks before his capture by U.S. forces.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Mariana Martínez and Tyler Pager
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: In his final weeks in power, President Nicolás Maduro still believed a deal with Washington was possible, people close to him said.

item.title: What to Know About the Cartels Operating in Mexico
item.description: Other criminal groups in Mexico may try to take advantage of the death of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes, also known as El Mencho, who ran the Jalisco New Generation Cartel.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Offerings of flowers, candles, photos and dollar bills at a shrine to Jesús Malverde — a “narco-saint,” in Culiacán, Sinaloa state, in 2024.

item.title: How the U.S. Is Crippling Cuba’s Economy
item.description: Cuba is facing its worst economic crisis in 67 years. Blackouts and fuel shortages have worsened after President Trump tightened restrictions on oil. Our international correspondent Frances Robles talks with Katrin Bennhold about the current situation in Cuba.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles, Katrin Bennhold, Leila Medina, Alexandra Ostasiewicz, Rafaela Balster and Parin Behrooz

item.title: Mexico Is Caught Between Trump and the Cartels
item.description: President Trump has demanded President Claudia Sheinbaum confront the cartels. The killing of El Mencho suggests it might be working — but could come at a cost.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Mandel Ngan
item.media:description: President Trump and President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico in Washington in December. Mr. Trump has been loudly and repeatedly demanding that Mexican officials dismantle the cartels.

item.title: Is It Safe to Travel to Mexico Right Now, Given the Cartel Violence?
item.description: A wave of unrest after the killing of a cartel leader has rattled tourists in Mexico, prompting travelers to reconsider their plans. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Shannon Sims
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Americans traveling in Guadalajara, Mexico, were still advised to “shelter in place” as of late Monday.

item.title: After Six Decades of War on Drugs, Does Anything Work?
item.description: The U.S. and its allies have spilled blood and treasure to kill drug lords and defeat cartels, but the drugs keep coming and the new groups are more violent than ever.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A burned car in Guadalajara following the capture and killing of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes.

item.title: After Chaos Rips Across Mexico, the Remnants of Cartel Violence Haunt Residents
item.description: Charred vehicles cluttered deserted streets as residents started to emerge from their homes in Guadalajara, which was hit hard by violence after the death of a cartel leader.
item.dc:creator: Paulina Villegas and César Rodríguez
item.media:credit: César Rodríguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Empty streets and closed businesses on Monday in downtown Guadalajara.

item.title: Hunkering Down in Mexico, Some Hope for a Flight Out Amid Burning Cars
item.description: People from Canada and the United States tell of scrambling for safety, food and flights after violence erupted in Mexico when a cartel boss died in custody.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: Tourists watching a smoke rising after cartel members blocked roads and burned down businesses after a military operation led to the death of the Mexican drug lord Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico.

item.title: Canada to Probe What OpenAI Knew About Tumbler Ridge Shooter
item.description: The company suspended the killer’s ChatGPT account over a policy violation in June, eight months before the attacks in Tumbler Ridge, British Columbia.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for the victims of a the mass shooting this month at Tumbler Ridge Secondary School in British Columbia.

item.title: Mexican Forces Say They Tracked El Mencho to Cabin by Following His Lover
item.description: Top security officials revealed details of the operation that led to the death of Mexico’s most wanted drug cartel leader.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Yuri Cortez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gen. Ricardo Trevilla Trejo, Mexico’s defense minister, described this weekend’s operation against a top cartel leader at a news conference in Mexico City on Monday with President Claudia Sheinbaum.

item.title: C.I.A. Intelligence Helped Lead Mexican Authorities to ‘El Mencho’
item.description: Mexican officials said they had found the elusive cartel kingpin by tracking a romantic partner. The C.I.A. provided some intelligence critical to the operation.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Alfredo Estrella/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mexican special forces in Mexico City on Sunday. C.I.A. intelligence helped lead the special forces to the cartel leader.

item.title: Videos Show How Violence Unfolded in Mexico After Killing of Cartel Boss
item.description: Armed groups blocked roads and set fire to supermarkets and banks after the Mexican government killed Mexico’s most-wanted cartel boss.
item.dc:creator: Devon Lum and Pablo Robles

item.title: What Travelers Need to Know as Cartel Violence Rattles Mexico
item.description: The killing of a drug lord and the unrest that followed prompted flight cancellations, roadblocks, cruise disruptions and “shelter in place” alerts.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Hiltner
item.media:credit: Ulises Ruiz/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mayhem after the killing of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes, who led a powerful criminal group, disrupted flights at Guadalajara International Airport on Sunday.

item.title: Puerto Vallarta Jolted By Violence After Cartel Boss Killing
item.description: When violence broke out after the killing of Mexico’s most-wanted cartel boss, vacation spots ordinarily spared from the drug wars were also targeted.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and David Shortell
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: Firefighters work to extinguish a bus on fire in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, Sunday.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and James Wagner

item.title: Supreme Court Considers Fate of Docks and Other Assets Seized by Cuba in 1960
item.description: Amid rising tensions with Cuba, the Trump administration is backing lawsuits that would allow Americans to get compensation for property confiscated by Fidel Castro’s regime.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Havana Docks Company
item.media:description: Revolutionaries confiscated the property of the Havana Docks Company in 1960.

item.title: Drug Lord ‘El Mencho’ Was Killed in Mexico. What’s Next for the Cartel He Led?
item.description: The death of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes dealt a major blow to the Jalisco New Generation Cartel, but few believe it spells the end for the powerful group.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Alfredo Estrella/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Security forces patrolling in Mexico City after the killing of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes on Sunday.

item.title: What to Know About the Killing of ‘El Mencho’
item.description: The Mexican government has killed Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes, the longtime leader of one of Mexico’s most powerful gangs, the Jalisco New Generation Cartel.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Ulises Ruiz/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Firefighters extinguishing a burning bus blocking a roadway in Jalisco state, Mexico, on Sunday.

item.title: ‘This Has Been a Day:’ U.S.-Canada Hockey Game Puts Rivalry on the Line
item.description: Canadians and Americans jammed bars that opened early on Sunday to watch the United States deal the Canadian team, and the country, a devastating blow in overtime.
item.dc:creator: Shawna Richer and Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the Canuck in Manhattan on Sunday, a handful of U.S. fans watched among a largely pro-Canada crowd.

item.title: ‘The Waterfall’ Review: A Mother’s Blessing and a Daughter’s Burden
item.description: Phanésia Pharel’s wistful two-hander starring Patrice Johnson Chevannes and Natalie Paul looks at a Haitian American family and questions of legacy.
item.dc:creator: Rhoda Feng

item.title: Mexican Forces Kill ‘El Mencho,’ Nation’s Most-Wanted Cartel Boss
item.description: “El Mencho” was the longtime head of one of the nation’s most powerful cartels. Armed groups set fire to cars and buildings across Mexico in the wake of his death.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Paulina Villegas
item.media:credit: Gilberto Gallo/Reuters
item.media:description: Agentes de policía aseguran una zona en la que miembros del crimen organizado incendiaron vehículos en Zapopan, México, el domingo.

item.title: Fat Signing Bonuses, and Concierge Service, for Family Doctors
item.description: In a country where a quarter of the population lacks a family doctor, Canadian communities compete in a zero-sum battle to recruit family doctors.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Gavin John
item.media:credit: Gavin John for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town of Stettler, Alberta’s economy is predominantly driven by the agriculture and oil industries, and is the largest town for surrounding communities.
